data.chText: （尤指正式地或法律上）同意，准予，允许
data.enText: to agree to give sb what they ask for, especially formal or legal permission to do sth

data.chText: 银行终于同意给我贷款500英镑。

data.hoverText: 动词+名词短语+名词短语

data.enText: The bank finally granted a £500 loan to me.

data.chText: 银行终于同意给我贷款500英镑。
data.enText: The bank finally granted me a £500 loan.

data.chText: 我的请求得到批准。
data.enText: My request was granted.

data.chText: 我获准参观宫殿。

data.hoverText: 动词+名词短语+名词短语

data.enText: I was granted permission to visit the palace.

data.chText: 她获准离婚。
data.enText: She was granted a divorce.

data.chText: （勉强）承认，同意
data.enText: to admit that sth is true, although you may not like or agree with it

data.chText: 我同意你的观点，她是一个很聪明的女人，但绝不是天才。
data.enText: She's a smart woman, I grant you, but she's no genius.

data.chText: 我承认你说的，它好看，可并不实用。

data.hoverText: 动词+名词短语 (+ that从句)

data.enText: I grant you (that) it looks good, but it's not exactly practical.
take it for granted (that…)

data.chText: 认为…是理所当然
data.enText: to believe sth is true without first making sure that it is

data.chText: 我还想当然地以为他总能随叫随到呢。
data.enText: I just took it for granted that he'd always be around.
take sb/sth for granted

data.chText: （因习以为常）对…不予重视；（因视为当然而）不把…当回事
data.enText: to be so used to sb/sth that you do not recognize their true value any more and do not show that you are grateful

data.chText: 她丈夫随时都在身边，她只是认为他理应如此。
data.enText: Her husband was always there and she just took him for granted.

data.chText: 我们想当然地认为洁净水的供应无穷无尽而不予以珍惜。
data.enText: We take having an endless supply of clean water for granted.

data.chText: （政府、机构的）拨款
data.enText: a sum of money that is given by the government or by another organization to be used for a particular purpose

data.chText: 学生助学金
data.enText: student grants (= to pay for their education)

data.chText: 他得到一笔研究经费。
data.enText: He has been awarded a research grant.

data.text: admit ♦ acknowledge ♦ concede ♦ confess ♦ allow ♦ grant

data.chText: 以上各词均含承认之义，常指不情愿地承认某事属实。
data.enText: These words all mean to agree, often unwillingly, that sth is true.
admit

data.chText: 指承认（常指不情愿地承认某事属实）：
data.enText: to agree, often unwillingly, that sth is true

data.chText: 我承认，那次干的是件蠢事。
data.enText: It was a stupid thing to do, I admit.
acknowledge

data.chText: 指承认某事物存在或属实：
data.enText: ( rather formal ) to accept that sth exists, is true or has happened

data.chText: 她拒不承认改革的必要性。
data.enText: She refuses to acknowledge the need for reform.
concede

data.chText: 指承认（常指不情愿地承认某事属实或合乎逻辑）：
data.enText: ( rather formal ) to admit, often unwillingly, that sth is true or logical

data.chText: 他被迫承认可能有困难。
data.enText: He was forced to concede (that) there might be difficulties.

data.chText: 用admit还是concede？
admit通常指承认普遍认为不好或错误的事情属实或确实发生过，尤指与自己行为有关。concede通常指勉强承认某事属实或某种说法合乎逻辑。
data.enText: When sb admits sth, they are usually agreeing that sth which is generally considered bad or wrong is true or has happened, especially when it relates to their own actions. When sb concedes sth, they are usually accepting, unwillingly, that a particular fact or statement is true or logical.
admit or concede?
confess

data.chText: 指承认自己感到羞愧或尴尬的事：
data.enText: ( rather formal ) to admit sth that you feel ashamed or embarrassed about

data.chText: 她不愿意承认自己无知。
data.enText: She was reluctant to confess her ignorance.
allow

data.chText: 指同意某事属实或正确：
data.enText: ( formal ) to agree that sth is true or correct

data.chText: 他拒不承认这种情况有可能发生。
data.enText: He refuses to allow that such a situation could arise.
grant

data.chText: 指同意某种说法属实，但通常同时否认另一过头说法：
data.enText: to admit that a statement or claim is true, usually while denying that a greater claim is also true

data.chText: 我同意，她是一个很聪明的女人，但并不是天才。
data.enText: She's an intelligent woman, I grant you, but she's no genius.

data.chText: 的确，他是个初学者，但基本规则他应该懂啊。
data.enText: Granted, he is a beginner, but he should know the basic rules.
to admit/acknowledge/concede/confess/allow/grant that…
to admit/confess to sth
to admit/concede/confess sth to sb
you must admit/acknowledge/concede/confess/allow/grant sth
to hate to admit/confess sth
to admit/acknowledge the truth
to admit/confess your mistakes/ignorance

means: (尤指正式地或法律上)同意，准予，允许

data.enText: take it for granted (that…)

data.chText: 认为…是理所当然
data.enText: to believe sth is true without first making sure that it is

data.chText: 我还想当然地以为他总能随叫随到呢。
data.enText: I just took it for granted that he'd always be around.
take sb/sth for granted

data.chText: （因习以为常）对…不予重视；（因视为当然而）不把…当回事
data.enText: to be so used to sb/sth that you do not recognize their true value any more and do not show that you are grateful

data.chText: 她丈夫随时都在身边，她只是认为他理应如此。
data.enText: Her husband was always there and she just took him for granted.

data.chText: 我们想当然地认为洁净水的供应无穷无尽而不予以珍惜。
data.enText: We take having an endless supply of clean water for granted.

tr: the act of providing a subsidy
a right or privilege that has been granted
a contract granting the right to operate a subsidiary business
example: he got the beer concession at the ball park

tr: (law) a transfer of property by deed of conveyance

example: Mandela was allowed few visitors in prison

tr: give as judged due or on the basis of merit
Funds are granted to qualified researchers"
example: the referee awarded a free kick to the team
the jury awarded a million dollars to the plaintiff

tr: surrender or relinquish to the physical control of another

example: This bill grants us new rights

value.def: A grant is an amount of money that a government or other institution gives to an individual or to an organization for a particular purpose such as education or home improvements.

example.ex: They'd got a special grant to encourage research...
example.tran: 他们得到一笔用以鼓励科研的特别经费。

example.ex: Unfortunately, my application for a grant was rejected.
example.tran: 很遗憾，我的助学金申请被拒绝了。

value.def: If someone in authority grants you something, or if something is granted to you, you are allowed to have it.

example.ex: France has agreed to grant him political asylum...
example.tran: 法国已经同意给予他政治避难。

example.ex: It was a Labour government which granted independence to India and Pakistan...
example.tran: 是工党政府同意了印度和巴基斯坦的独立。

example.ex: Permission was granted a few weeks ago.

value.def: If you grant that something is true, you accept that it is true, even though your opinion about it does not change.

example.ex: The magistrates granted that the charity was justified in bringing the action.
example.tran: 地方法官承认该慈善机构有理由提起诉讼。

defx.def: You use 'I grant you' or 'I'll grant you' to say that you accept something is true, even though your opinion about it does not change.
defx.tran: 我承认（某事属实，但并不因此改变自己的观点）

example.ex: He took a risk, I'll grant you. But when you think about it, the risk was pretty small...
example.tran: 我承认他有些冒险，但是回过来想一想，其实风险并不大。

example.ex: I grant you that there have been excesses here and there. But this happens in any popular national struggle.
example.tran: 我承认各地出现了一些过激行为，但是这种现象在任何大规模民族斗争中都在所难免。

value.def: If you say that someone takes you for granted, you are complaining that they benefit from your help, efforts, or presence without showing that they are grateful.

example.ex: What right has the family to take me for granted, Martin?...
example.tran: 这家人有什么资格瞧不起我，马丁？

example.ex: The officials felt taken for granted and grumbled loudly.
example.tran: 这些官员感到受了怠慢，于是大声抱怨起来。

value.tran: （因视作理所当然而）不把…当回事，对…不予重视（或不知感激）

value.def: If you take something for granted, you believe that it is true or accept it as normal without thinking about it.

example.ex: I was amazed that virtually all the things I took for granted up north just didn't happen in London.
example.tran: 几乎所有我认为在北方是理所当然的事情在伦敦都没有发生，这让我惊诧不已。

value.def: If you take it for granted that something is the case, you believe that it is true or you accept it as normal without thinking about it.

example.ex: He seemed to take it for granted that he should speak as a representative.
example.tran: 他似乎想当然地认为他应该以代表的身份发言。
